I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy  2020  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identifies  private  sector 
development and private sector operations as key drivers of change in Asia and the Pacific.1 
Under  Strategy  2020,  ADB  will  expand  work  with  the  private  sector  to  generate  greater 
economic growth in the region. Public–private partnerships (PPPs) are seen as an important 
modality to achieve this objective, and the strategy emphasizes the promotion of PPPs in all of 
ADB’s  core  operations. This  is  reinforced  in  the  Midterm  Review  of Strategy  2020,  which 
contemplates  ADB  assuming  a  more  active  role  in  project  development  and  resource 
mobilization to prepare bankable PPP projects.2 
2.  The  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Enhancing  Public–Private 
Partnership  Projects  through  Support  for  Law  and  Policy  Development  and  Transaction 
Advisory Services will directly contribute to three pillars of ADB’s Public–Private Partnership 
Operational Plan, 2012–2020.3 The TA will enhance the ability of ADB’s developing member 
countries (DMCs) to structure and procure bankable PPP projects, provide an enabling legal 
environment, improve project documentation, and provide capacity development. The TA will 
also be used to support specific initiatives requested by DMCs in coordination with relevant 
regional departments and resident missions.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  DMCs face a critical gap in delivering modern and efficient infrastructure services, but a 
significant amount of private sector capital is not invested in infrastructure development in 
DMCs  owing  to  a  dearth  of  well-structured,  viable  investment  opportunities.  Asia’s  overall 
national  infrastructure  investment  needs  during  2010–2020  are  estimated  at  
$8 trillion: 68% for new capacity and 32% for maintaining and replacing existing infrastructure.5 
ADB’s $11.02 billion sovereign and nonsovereign lending portfolio for infrastructure and the 
World  Bank’s  $23.00  billion  portfolio  can  only make  a modest  contribution  to the region’s 
growing demand for infrastructure investment. Primary development constraints include (i) legal 
and regulatory impediments, (ii) lack of precedent documentation, and (iii) public sector capacity 
constraints. 
 
4.  Legal and regulatory impediments. ADB provides transaction advisory services to 
assist DMC clients in developing bankable projects to facilitate private sector investment and 
thereby  ameliorate  the  infrastructure  deficit  and  reduce  the  financial  burdens  on  DMC 
governments and their public sector budgets. Private sector investment will encourage the 
efficient use of resources, as well as improvements in asset and service quality, public sector 
management,  and  public  sector  procurement.  However,  the  level  and  effectiveness  of 
engagement has, to date, been limited by deficiencies in the broad legal and policy frameworks, 
which do not provide an environment supportive of private sector investment in general and

Manila. 
2  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2012. Public–Private Partnership Operational Plan, 2012–2020 – Realizing the Vision for Strategy 2020: The 
Transformational Role of Public–Private Partnerships in Asian Development Bank Operations. Manila. Pillar 1: 
Advocacy and capacity development for PPPs; pillar 2: Enabling environment to develop policy, legal, regulatory, 
and institutional framework to facilitate, guide, and manage the development of PPPs; and pillar 3: Develop

4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 October 2015. 
5  ADB and the Asian Development Bank Institute. 2009. Infrastructure for a Seamless Asia. Manila.

2  
PPP in particular. For example, in DMCs with less-developed PPP markets, ADB has identified 
a need to draft and pass legislation to provide the proper enabling environment. Where PPP-
enabling legislation exists, laws, regulations, and practices often impede the progress of PPP 
projects. These issues negatively impact the PPP process by elevating regulatory risks and 
project risks, and therefore reduce the likelihood that a pipeline of bankable projects can be 
developed in the relevant DMC. 
 
5.  Lack  of  model  documentation.  Large  and  complex  PPP  transactions  tend  to  be 
documentation intensive. Significant time and costs are typically required to ensure that all 
aspects of the contractual matrix are properly documented from a legal perspective. In more 
mature PPP markets, precedent documentation is often available to reduce the time and costs 
incurred in documenting PPP transactions and to help focus negotiations on issues unique or 
specific to the project or transaction. Less-developed PPP markets could likewise benefit from 
building up a stock of precedent or model documentation that could be used for replicating 
successful PPP projects. ADB’s work on first-in-kind “pathfinder” projects has created invaluable 
documentary precedents that could, and should, be adapted to become market and/or industry 
standards  in  the  relevant  DMCs.  This  would  allow  similar  projects  to  be  procured  more 
efficiently and cost-effectively.6 
 
6.  Capacity  constraints.  DMCs  also  face  capacity  and  resource  constraints  more 
generally in relation to structuring and procuring PPP projects. ADB’s Office of Public–Private 
Partnership (OPPP) has identified several DMCs that are seeking ADB assistance in setting up 
centralized PPP centers to coordinate the priority and rollout of PPP projects, and putting in 
place the necessary regulatory platforms to empower the PPP centers. In some cases, this 
includes putting in place processes to devolve that power to the implementing agencies for 
bidding to the private sector. These DMCs have expressed the need for continued professional 
support for capacity development through training sessions, workshops, and seminars to build 
on the existing knowledge base and help close the skills gap.  
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be the requirements of three pillars of ADB’s Public–Private Partnership 
Operational Framework are addressed (pillar 1: advocacy and capacity development; pillar 2: 
enabling environment; and pillar 3: project development). ADB’s regional departments can then 
work  with  DMCs  to  identify  projects  and  start  specific  project  development  (pillar  4).  The 
outcome  will  be  a  strengthened  business  environment  in  the  DMCs  to  promote  private 
investment in infrastructure. The TA is expected to deliver the following outputs: (i) policy and 
legal frameworks for private sector investment, (ii) model documentation for PPP projects, and 
(iii) improved skills and knowledge of relevant government stakeholders on PPP structuring and 
procurement.   
 
 
                                                
6  For example, the development of a bankable power purchase agreement early in the independent power producer 
program in Thailand has allowed subsequent independent power producers in the country to be structured more 
efficiently around the power purchase agreement template.

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Output 1: Law and policy documents. The component will improve the legal and 
regulatory  environment  to  support  the  continuing  development  of  bankable  PPP  projects. 
Diagnostics will be conducted on the existing legal and regulatory framework in the relevant 
DMCs to determine if the laws and regulations in place are adequate. Consultations will be held 
with key public sector stakeholders and interested private sector investors to identify the nature 
and scope of required reforms for the legal and regulatory framework (considering international 
and regional best practice and bankability issues). Finally, the TA will support the drafting of 
policy documents (e.g., white papers and policy guidance) or amended primary and secondary 
legislation to provide workable solutions to promote PPP projects and private sector investment.  
 
9.  Output 2: Model documentation. The component will support DMC efforts to ensure 
adequate and appropriate template documentation is available to support PPP projects. The TA 
will support reviews of precedent project documentation for projects that have successfully 
achieved  financial  close  in  the  relevant  DMC,  including  concession  agreements,  supply 
agreements, offtake agreements, financial documents and direct agreements, host government 
support agreements (including guarantees), and regulatory instruments (e.g., licenses). Model 
documents will then be developed, either on a generic basis (i.e., for general application to PPP 
projects as a whole) or on a sector-specific basis (i.e., tailored for a particular class of PPP 
projects in a given industry sector).7  
 
10.  Output 3: Capacity-building workshops and training. The component will address 
capacity constraints within DMCs to improve their ability to administer and implement PPP 
projects. Training sessions and workshops will be provided on the implementation of the law 
and/or policy documents prepared, and model documentation created. Stand-alone training 
sessions and workshops may be provided to assist DMCs in structuring and procuring PPP 
projects, and attracting private sector investment for infrastructure development. Workshops 
and training will be designed to suit the needs of participants. Site visits and study tours for key 
DMC agency stakeholders may be supported, provided there is strong justification. 
 
11.  The TA is expected to provide discrete and targeted interventions on a flexible, demand-
oriented basis. The selection of specific projects will be determined by the Office of the General 
Counsel (OGC) in consultation with OPPP and the relevant regional departments and resident 
missions. Priority will be given to projects in DMCs with nascent or emerging PPP markets. 
Prospective projects for TA support include, but are not limited to, the following:  
 
(i)  Nepal:  The  government  has  requested  capacity-building  assistance  to  help 
procuring  authorities  understand  the  complexities  of  PPP  projects.  The 
Investment Board of Nepal made this request at an OPPP mission to Kathmandu 
in late September 2015.8  
 
(ii)   Viet Nam: OGC and OPPP understand (from missions to Viet Nam earlier in 
2015) that the Ministry of Planning and Investment is in the process of preparing 
model  concession  agreements.  OGC  has  consulted  informally  with  ADB’s 
Southeast Asia Regional Department to assess if the provision of TA support for

8  OGC and OPPP have been in contact with the Nepal Resident Mission to arrange a follow-up mission (November 
2015) to discuss capacity-building support for the Investment Board of Nepal in greater detail.

the preparation of these agreements would be appropriate. OGC and OPPP will 
liaise with the Viet Nam Resident Mission in due course to arrange a mission to 
ascertain the current priorities of the Ministry of Planning and Investment in 
relation to PPP-related legal work. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,000,000 from TASF-V and $400,000 from TASF-
other  sources).  Detailed  cost  estimates  and  the  financial  plan  are  in  Appendix  2.  DMCs 
receiving support under this TA will be expected to provide in-kind counterpart support by 
providing  secretariat  staff,  local  office  accommodation,  office  supplies,  and  domestic 
transportation, as appropriate. Where appropriate, DMC governments may also be required to 
provide cash contributions (e.g., by way of monthly retainer fees to reimburse or defray ADB’s 
travel and incremental overhead costs), particularly if support under the TA is provided in 
conjunction with OPPP’s transaction advisory services.9 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  Executing and implementing agencies. ADB will be the executing agency through 
OGC and OPPP. OGC will be responsible for overall TA administration and supervision, and will 
engage the required consultants. OGC and OPPP will work closely with relevant participating 
DMC agencies. These agencies are expected to take ownership of outputs 1 and 2. OGC and 
OPPP will consult and involve relevant regional departments and resident missions to draw on 
their country and sector expertise as appropriate. OGC and OPPP will be jointly accountable for 
delivering the TA outputs. The TA will be implemented from January 2016 to December 2018. 
 
14.  Engagement  of  consultants. The TA will require the services of international and 
national law firms, qualified to advise on the laws of the relevant jurisdictions. These law firms 
will be engaged as needed to deliver outputs 1 and 2. Other consultants with relevant expertise 
(e.g., management specialists, accountants, and/or project finance specialists) may also be 
required (e.g., to assist in developing policy frameworks). Where appropriate, OGC will consult 
with ADB’s Operations Services and Financial Management Department to determine the scope 
of  work,  detailed  terms  of  reference,  and  selection  process  for  the  consultants  once  the 
activities  requiring  consultant  inputs  are  identified  and  agreed  with  the  relevant  DMCs. 
International and national consultants will also be appointed as required for the implementation 
of output 3. Consultants will be recruited using the appropriate selection methods following 
ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).10 
Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
15.  Monitoring and evaluation. Each project supported by the TA will be monitored and 
evaluated based on the implementation of activities and satisfactory delivery of outputs following 
the agreed timeline and budget allocation for the project. OGC envisages frequent interaction 
with the TA consultants, which will facilitate the monitoring of progress and assessment of 
performance. TA outputs and work products (e.g., draft laws, policy documents, and model

appropriate, these outputs and work products will be supported by capacity-building sessions to 
ensure that the DMC agency client is able to maximize value from them. 
 
16.  Complementarity.  The  TA  is  intended  to  supplement  other  PPP-focused  ADB 
resources (e.g., OPPP’s TA support of transaction advisory services, and the Asia Pacific 
Project Preparation Facility) by providing discrete, targeted support.11 In implementing the TA, 
OGC  will  ensure  appropriate  coordination  with  OPPP,  regional  departments,  and  resident 
missions to promote a “one ADB” approach and to minimize the risk of overlap and duplication 
of effort. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,400,000 on a grant basis 
for  Enhancing  Public–Private  Partnership  Projects  through  Support  for  Law  and  Policy 
Development and Transaction Advisory Services, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.    The  technical  assistance  (TA)  may  require  an  international  legal  consultant  and  a 
national legal consultant, with the international legal consultant taking the lead. The precise 
arrangements will depend on project-specific requirements and the consultants involved. As 
projects are expected to be jurisdiction-specific, more than one set of consultants may be 
appointed for each output (either concurrently or sequentially) where more than one jurisdiction 
is involved. Detailed terms (including the precise scope and time frames for engagement) for the 
legal consultants will be prepared on a project-specific basis at TA implementation. 
 
A.   Output 1: Law and Policy Documents 
 
2.  International legal consultant. A leading international law firm with experience in legal 
and regulatory reform will be expected to 
(i)  take the lead in proposing and drafting new laws and/or policy documents in 
consultation  with  the  developing  member  country  (DMC)  client,  considering 
international best practice (if any) and the requirements of the domestic market in 
question; 
(ii)  identify and advise on 
(a)   appropriate  legal  models  and  approaches  (drawing  particularly  on 
experience or case studies from jurisdictions with similar legal systems to 
the DMC client), and 
(b)   key legal and policy risks; 
(iii)  supervise and manage the national consultant; and 
(iv)  document key policy objectives underpinning the proposed reforms. 
 
3.   National legal consultant. A local law specialist (who may or may not be affiliated with 
the international consultant) will be expected to 
(i)  conduct due diligence on the existing legal and regulatory framework to identify 
areas requiring reform to attract greater private sector investment; and 
(ii)  advise on key local law issues and constraints. 
 
4.   Translations. Where required, legal translations will be prepared (or procured by) the 
international or national consultant, as appropriate. 
 
B.  Output 2: Model Documentation 
 
5.  International  legal  consultant.  A  leading  international  law  firm  with  experience 
handling projects in the sector in question (e.g., energy, transport) will be expected to 
(i)  take the lead in 
(a)   reviewing existing project documentation (if any) to advise on key legal 
risks, bankability concerns, and drafting deficiencies; and/or  
(b)   developing new project and/or financing documents in consultation with the 
DMC client, considering international best practice (if any); 
(ii)  prepare model documentation using existing project documentation (where these 
exist) or developing new documentation (where appropriate); and 
(iii)  supervise and manage the national consultant. 
 
6.  National legal consultant. A local law specialist (who may or may not be affiliated with 
the international consultant) will be expected to

10   
 
 
(i)  advise on the general legal and regulatory aspects applicable to the project-
specific and model documents, and 
(ii)  advise on key local law issues and constraints as relevant to the project-specific 
and model documents. 
 
7.  Translations. Where required, legal translations will be prepared (or procured by) the 
international or national consultant, as appropriate. 
 
C.  Output 3: Capacity-Building 
 
8.  International and national legal consultants. International and national consultants 
working on output 1 and output 2 projects will be required to 
(i)  assist with the relevant country consultations;  
(ii)  organize and/or support training workshops; and 
(iii)  ensure that the key stakeholders are properly briefed as to the purpose and 
contents of the revised law and/or policy documents or the model documentation 
(as appropriate) to enable them to effectively implement the revised law and/or 
policy documents or to administer the model documentation (as appropriate).  
 
9.  The consultants may additionally be appointed on an ad hoc basis to deliver stand-alone 
training sessions and workshops (which are not tied to output 1 or output 2 projects). 
   
10.  Translations Where appropriate, the international or national consultant will prepare (or 
procure) the translation of training materials and arrange for training sessions to be conducted 
in the relevant local language. 
 
D.  Other Consultants 
11.  Where  appropriate,  other  consultants  (e.g.,  management  consultants,  accountants, 
and/or project finance specialists) may be appointed instead of or in addition to the legal 
consultants. These appointments are considered to be unlikely as the TA is principally a law, 
justice, and development TA. Detailed terms of references (including the precise scope and time 
frames for engagement) for these other consultants will be prepared on a project-specific basis 
at TA implementation.
